body.p: The Governor of Kentucky your Petitioner John Rice states to you that the may Term of the Magoffin Circuit Court in 1865 The Grand Jury at that Term Indicted him for Tipling (that is for two acts of selling sprituous Liquor. I was guilty of selling only on one occasion & that in case of Sickness I advised with an attorny who informed me that I had best Confess Judgment & ask your clemency I accordingly confessed Judgment for $60 -- when in fact & in truth I have only been guilty of the one act of selling in violation of the Laws -- we have been Living for several years without Courts or Law & it was a very hard matter for Union men who remained here to sell any way -- I am no Grocer or Tavern Keeper I had a small quantity of Apples which I distilled & had some little apple Brandy on hand this selling that I have Confessed is all that I Sold by the Small have no more on hand -- & will not again be caught I am a Poor man & have a wife & several children to support a small mountain farm to make a Living on for them & if I am Compelled to pay the Judgmt it will deprive my family of actual Comforts of Life & it will not be felt by the State hence I verry Respectfully ask your Excellency to Remit said Fine 14' June 1865

June Term 1864
Fines in A P Cooprs office as J P M C
to
Andrew howard for
one for -- $20.00
one for. -- 5 00
one for -- 2.46
have them Remited for Howard if it can be done

John Rice
Petition to the Governor
I believe the facts stated in the petition of Mr Rice to be correct
